div.p:
I sent a
note to Mr MacGregor
last night desiring
him to apply to
you for the map
as I mean to
say a little at
Manchester.Aand
I hope he may
find you still
at Dublin. I quite
forgot to accept
of the offer you
made & bring it
with me. I was
a little bewildered
I suppose. If you
are still in Dublin
bBe kind enough
to give it to him
and he will forward
it to Manchester
whither I am going
tomorrow. Tthe children go to Scotland at the
same time.

Captain Toynbee
has been looking
over my observations
and is much
pleased with them. You remember
Sir Roderick send
sendno text that the R.G.S.
would publish them.
Now I wish to put the
results i.e. a table
of the Latitudes and
Longitudes at the
end of the book.
Would that interfere
with the publication
of them by the
society with Captain
Toynbee's remarks?
The Admiral has
undertaken to correct
the press - and CapnToynbee thinks they may prove useful to
travellers. Would you drop a line to say if I
may put in the table. Many of them have been
already published in
your journal.

Have you heard anything of a
steamer for the Zambesi?

I heard a little just before leaving
Dublin on Ttuesday
